title: Ex-cop who shot dead black Air Force veteran is found not guilty of murder
text:
A former Georgia police officer who fatally shot an unarmed, naked man was found not guilty of murder on Monday.

Jurors did convict Robert 'Chip' Olsen of aggravated assault, violation of oath of office and making a false statement. His wife began sobbing when she heard the verdict.

A judge was deliberating whether to grant bond for Olsen or keep him in custody until his sentencing on November 1.

Olsen, now 57, was a DeKalb County police officer in March 2015 when he responded to a call of a naked man behaving erratically outside the Heights of Chamblee apartment complex in Atlanta.

Shortly after arriving, he fatally shot 26-year-old Anthony Hill, an Air Force veteran who had been diagnosed with bipolar disorder and Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder. A grand jury indicted Olsen nearly a year after the shooting.

Former Georgia police officer, Robert 'Chip' Olsen (pictured), who fatally shot shot unarmed Anthony Hill, 26, in March 2015 was found not guilty of murder on Monday

But jurors did convict Olsen (pictured) of aggravated assault, violation of oath of office and making a false statement. His wife began sobbing when she heard the verdict

Olsen, now 57, was a DeKalb County police officer in March 2015 when he responded to a call of a naked man behaving erratically outside an Atlanta-area apartment complex. That man was later identified as Hill (left and right)

In the Olsen case, the apartment complex property manager testified that she saw Hill, a resident of the complex, wearing shorts but no shoes or shirt and behaving strangely on March 9, 2015.

After maintenance workers got him to go to his apartment, he reemerged a short time later without any clothes.

The property manager, who testified that she was worried for Hill's safety because he was behaving so bizarrely, called 911 three times.

Olsen was told by dispatch there was a naked man who was 'possibly demented'.

Hill was seen in still images from surveillance footage climbing over balconies and crawling along the floor.

BREAKING: Verdict reached in Robert Olsen trial BREAKING: Verdict reached in Robert Olsen trial Posted by CBS46 on Monday, 14 October 2019

When Olsen arrived, Hill was squatting in a roadway but jumped up and ran toward the patrol car, according to testimony from several witnesses.

Olsen exited his car and yelled, 'Stop! Stop!' Hill didn't stop, and Olsen shot him twice, witnesses said.

At the time, Hill's girlfriend Bridget Anderson revealed he was being treated by a Veterans' Association (VA) doctor for bipolar disorder but stopped taking the medication a week or two before because he didn't like the side effects, including stiffening in his jaw.

She described how she was on the way to his house to cook and celebrate their three-year anniversary when she found out he was dead.

Hill had served more than four years in the Air Force when he was medically discharged.

In the Olsen (left) case, the apartment complex property manager testified that she saw Hill (right), a resident of the complex, wearing shorts but no shoes or shirt and behaving strangely on March 9, 2015

At the time, Hill's girlfriend Bridget Anderson (left and right with Hill) revealed he was being treated by a Veterans' Association doctor for bipolar disorder but stopped taking the medication a week before because he didn't like the side effects, including stiffening in his jaw

The property manager, who testified that she was worried for Hill's safety because he was behaving so bizarrely, called 911 three times. Hill's death prompted protests (pictured) in Georgia

Hill was in the roadway when Olsen arrived but jumped up and ran toward the patrol car, according to testimony from witnesses. Olsen exited his car and yelled, 'Stop! Stop!' Hill didn't stop, and Olsen shot him twice, witnesses said. Protesters are seen after the 2015 shooting

His death prompted more than 100 demonstrators to gather in Decatur to protest the killing.

Prosecutors argued that Olsen unreasonably and unnecessarily used deadly force to deal with the unarmed, naked man who was suffering a mental health crisis.

Defense attorneys countered that Olsen had limited information about the situation, was scared to death and had only seconds to make a tough decision.

During closing arguments, lawyers for both sides told jurors they needed to decide whether Olsen's actions were reasonable given the situation.

Monday's verdict comes on the heels of a jury in Texas finding a white former Dallas police officer guilty of murder in the shooting death of a black man.

Amber Guyger was returning home after a long shift when she shot Botham Jean. Guyger testified that she mistook Jean's apartment for her own, which was one floor below, and that she thought he was a burglar in her home.

She was convicted October 1 and was sentenced to serve 10 years in prison.

A few days later, on October 5, a jury in southeastern Georgia found a white former police officer who fatally shot a fleeing, unarmed black man not guilty on charges of voluntary and involuntary manslaughter.

Jurors found Zechariah Presley guilty of violating his oath of office in the 2018 shooting of Tony Green in coastal Camden County, near the Georgia-Florida state line.
